subject: theory parameter suppliers
msgSnippet: The popper tutorial that the junit 4.4 release notes refers to shows an example of a parameter supplier, which allows data points for theories to come from
messageBody:
The popper tutorial that the junit 4.4 release notes refers to shows
an example of a parameter supplier, which allows data points for
theories to come from parameters of an annotation:

http://popper.tigris.org/tutorial.html

The example allows you to use the parameters of an annotation as
parameters for the theory:

@Theory public void multiplyIsInverseOfDivideWithInlineDataPoints(
@Between(first=-100, last=100) int amount,
@Between(first=-100, last=100) int m
) {
assumeThat(m, not(0));
assertThat(new Dollar(amount).times(m).divideBy(m).getAmount(),
is(amount));
}

I think the parameters first and last have to be compile time
constants, is that right? How can I I test with parameters that
aren't constants? I wouldn't want to put 200 strings in the parameter
list, for example. I could use integers like the Between annotation
above, as indices into an array or function I guess.

I used the @Parameters JUnit annotation instead for a test. From what
I see so far, that looks to me like a simpler solution in general,
than using @Theory. Is that right?

Kendall
